Award.AwardTitle: The 14th International Conference on Inorganic Membranes (ICIM 2016)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET- 1648823 P.I.: Nair, Sankar
Institution: Georgia Tech Research Corporation
Title: The 14th International Conference on Inorganic Membranes (ICIM 2016)

This project will provide travel funds to partially support approximately 15-20 graduate and post doctoral students and junior faculty to attend the 14th International Conference on Inorganic Membranes (ICIM 2016) at Georgia Tech, in Atlanta, GA from July 10-13, 2016. ICIM is the premier and long-standing conference series in the field of inorganic membranes, and is held every two years. The previous (13th) meeting, ICIM 2014, was held July 6-9, 2014 in Brisbane, Australia. Inorganic membranes have shown clear potential to play a key role in solving important societal challenges such as efficient production of fuels, chemicals, renewable energy, and drinking water; as well as advanced environmental remediation and climate change mitigation. ICIM is the only international conference dedicated to the science, engineering, and industrial use of inorganic membranes.

Funding from the National Science Foundation would be used for student and postdoc conference expenses and junior faculty, enabling more US engineers and scientists to participate in ICIM 2016. The expected outcomes include:
1. Enable greater participation by junior faculty and graduate students and thus facilitating networking opportunities and establish new domestic and international collaborations with veteran researchers.
2. Creation of opportunities for students and faculty to share their accomplishments with peers and more senior members of the community. The feedback they receive can help direct their work and provide encouragement.
3. In addition to the development of human resources, the support provided will allow presentation of the latest research results from the most innovative academic laboratories around the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The 14th International Conference on Inorganic Membranes (ICIM 2016) was hosted by the Georgia Institute of Technology in the Georgia Tech Global Learning Center in Atlanta, Georgia. ICIM is the premier and long-standing conference series in the field of inorganic membranes, and is held every two years. Historically, the conference venue has rotated between the USA, Europe, and Asia-Pacific. The ICIM 2016 dates were July 10-13, 2016. NSF support was used to provide participant travel support, focusing (in order of priority) on underrepresented graduate students (US citizens/permanent residents), other US citizen/permanent resident graduates students, and other non-US citizen/permanent resident graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. 20 US and international participants were supported.

Intellectual Merit: ICIM is the only international conference dedicated to the science, engineering, and industrial use of inorganic membranes. The conference program featured 6 plenary lecture, 18 keynote lectures, ~75 contributed talks, and ~50 contributed posters. Building upon the success of previous ICIM conferences, the 14th edition of ICIM in 2016 presented a global perspective on key contemporary inorganic membrane topics covering the entire range of inorganic membrane types, application areas (with emphasis on chemical and biological separations), and technical areas (such as fabrication, characterization, modeling, scale-up, and industrialization).ICIM 2016 was a unique gathering of the world’s leading inorganic membrane experts who provided a cutting-edge perspective on how inorganic membranes can address major technological challenges. Furthermore, the plenary and keynote speakers provided leading-edge perspectives on the many facets of inorganic membrane science and technology. 

Broader Impact: Inorganic membranes have shown clear potential to play a key role in solving important technological and societal challenges in the 21st century such as efficient production of fuels, chemicals, renewable energy, and drinking water; as well as advanced environmental remediation and climate change mitigation. ICIM is the only international conference that brings together students, junior researchers, and established experts to disseminate and discuss the latest advances in this important area relevant to chemical and biological separation processes.

The ICIM program was designed to facilitate productive interactions between academic and industrial attendees (e.g., ~10% of the talks/posters being from industry, ~25% of sessions co-chaired by an industry representative, and 2 sessions focusing on scale-up and industrialization of inorganic membranes).

The ~160 attendees comprised a diverse group of students, postdoctoral fellows, faculty members, and industrial R&D/technology experts from more than 15 countries. The requested support had a particularly broad impact in enabling the participation of students and junior researchers who will constitute the next generation of researchers and technology leaders in the field of inorganic membranes. These NSF-supported participants disseminated their latest results in the form of oral presentations and posters at ICIM 2016.
